Award.AwardTitle: Financial Intermediaries in a Modern Economy: Risk Taking and Liquidity Provision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research team plans two projects that analyze two properties of modern banks. First, modern banks are exposed to risk not only through traditional ownership of risk assets (loans and securities) but also through their trading books, and in particular their positions from making markets in derivatives. The research team will develop a new approach to measure these risk exposures that uses regulatory data and the dynamics of interest rates. A second key property of modern banks is that they, along with other intermediaries such as financial clearinghouses, offer payment services to clients. The clients include households, firms, and institution investors such as broker-dealers and asset managers. Existing models of business cycles and asset prices do not typically include these payment services. The team will develop a model of the economy that includes such services and will use the model to quantify how inflation and asset prices respond to monetary policy and economic shocks. The research funded by this award will give policy makers and regulators new tools and models to predict the effects of economic policies.

Existing approaches to the measurement of this risk using regulatory or stock market data have not been able to compare time variation in risk across positions. For example, the measures cannot be used to determine whether derivative positions hedge other business. In practice regulators therefore rely on stress tests. The new approach exploits the factor structure in interest rates to represent many bank positions (including derivatives) in terms of simple factor portfolios. A transparent algorithm delivers, for every bank position and every date, exposure numbers that are comparable across dates, banks, and positions. The second project builds a dynamic equilibrium model in which goods and services are paid for with inside money provided by banks or clearinghouses. The model jointly determines asset prices and inflation as well as the volume of payments. The model includes data on payments and bank positions and uses the data to make quantitative predictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this NSF grant has produced two sets of results. First, we have developed measures of risk exposure for individual U.S. banks. These measures answer the question: how much is an individual bank exposed to changes in interest rates as well as credit risk. To address this question, we use regulatory data from the Call Reports which contain detailed information about the maturity of each bank position and its credit rating. We develop an econometric methodology to estimate the exposure through derivative holdings of individual banks. We find that banks’ risk exposures through derivatives further increase their risk exposure in their balance sheet. Our exposure measure provide a tool for policy makers and regulators to study the risk exposures of banks. Moreover, the quantitative results are a guide for theoretical models in economics that study the behavior of banks.

The second project provides policy makers with a new concept of money that is relevant for thinking about the impact of monetary policy. This concept relies on payments for goods as well as assets. We develop a model in which the impact of monetary policy depends on the financial structure: the leverage costs of banks, the composition of their assets, and the volume of asset trading by institutional investors.
